catalyst.context: Photocatalytic CO 2 reduction into renewable hydrocarbon solar fuels is considered as a promising strategy to simultaneously address the global energy and environmental issues.In this study, a binary g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO photocatalytic system was constructed via a one-step facile calcination method and further used as a photocatalyst for CO 2 reduction.It was shown that the as-prepared g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO photocatalytic system exhibited enhanced photocatalytic activity for CO 2 reduction by a factor of 2.3 compared with pure g-C 3 N 4 , while maintaining the original selectivity of pure g-C 3 N 4 to convert CO 2 directly into CH 3 OH.For the first time, the coupling effect of ZnO responsible for the improved photoactivity of g-C 3 N 4 was fully illustrated and a direct Z-scheme mechanism rather than the conventional heterojunction-type mechanism was proposed to explain the better performances of the g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO binary composite photocatalytic system.The enhancement of photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activity is attributed to the highly efficient ZnO-to-g-C 3 N 4 electron transfer occurring at the intimate contact interface between the g-C 3 N 4 phase and ZnO phase.This work will provide new deep insights into the rational construction of a g-C 3 N 4 -based photocatalytic system and the design of a direct Z-scheme system without an electron mediator for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction reactions.

respectively.The stronger peak at 27.4 which is attributed to the interlayer stacking of aromatic systems can be indexed to the (002) crystal plane and corresponds to an interlayer distance of 0.326 nm.The weaker (001) peak at around 13.1 with a distance of 0.675 nm can be ascribed to interlayer planar stacking motifs.These two characteristic peaks of pure g-C 3 N 4 are consistent with the previous results. 18,26,33The prepared pure ZnO demonstrates characteristic diffraction peaks with high intensities of the wurtzite hexagonal ZnO phase, which is the most stable and common form of ZnO under ambient conditions.The XRD pattern of the pure ZnO indicates that the wurtzite hexagonal ZnO crystals with high crystallinity can form under the synthetic conditions, which stems from the decomposition of zinc nitrate hexahydrate.For the obtained G10 sample, nearly all of the characteristic diffraction peaks of wurtzite hexagonal ZnO were clearly shown in its XRD pattern without any noticeable shis of diffraction angles (2q), conrming the existence of the ZnO phase.As for the g-C 3 N 4 phase, only the (002) peak of g-C 3 N 4 was obscurely observed whose diffraction intensity was lower compared with that of the ZnO phase.The relatively poor crystallinity of the g-C 3 N 4 phase indicates that the simultaneous crystallization of the ZnO phase interferes with the condensation process and interlayer stacking patterns of the g-C 3 N 4 phase, thus resulting in its weak diffraction intensity.The XRD patterns of both the ZnO phase and g-C 3 N 4 phase in the G10 sample suggest that these two phases exist separately in the composite and no strong crystal lattice incorporation is observed between these two phases. To investigate the thermostability and measure the g-C 3 N 4 contents in G10, TGA analyses were performed on both the obtained G10 and pure samples, from ambient temperature to 900 C at a heating rate of 10 C min A1 .The corresponding results are shown in Fig. 2. For the pure g-C 3 N 4 , the rapid decay of the TGA curve from around 450 C to 600 C represents the typical thermal decomposition of g-C 3 N 4 , indicating its intrinsic thermal instability in this temperature range.No signicant weight loss is observed in the TGA curve of pure ZnO, con-rming the high thermal stability of ZnO.Compared with pure g-C 3 N 4 , the TGA curve decay of the G10 sample starts and ends at lower temperatures, respectively.This suggests that the obtained G10 sample demonstrates lower thermal stability upon heating than the pure g-C 3 N 4 , which is mainly due to the disturbance of simultaneous ZnO crystallization towards interlayer stacking motifs of g-C 3 N 4 or the catalyzing effect of ZnO over g-C 3 N 4 thermal decomposition.A similar phenomenon was also observed in other cases such as g-C 3 N 4 /TiO 2 coupling. 44he relative content of the ZnO phase in the G10 sample is determined to be 44.6,accounting for nearly half the weight composition of G10.Considering the original mass ratio of the precursors of g-C 3 N 4 (urea) and ZnO (zinc nitrate hexahydrate) to be around 10, a signicant amount of urea is estimated to undergo direct thermal decomposition into gases during polycondensation, 45 because the holding temperature of condensation is precisely within the above measured temperature range for pure g-C 3 N 4 decomposition. XPS analyses were performed to investigate the chemical composition and elucidate the elemental chemical states of all samples.As expected, there are four major elemental states detected in the prepared G10 samples, namely C 1s, N 1s, Zn 2p and O 1s.Fig. 3a-d present the comparison of the high-resolution XPS spectra of C 1s, N 1s, Zn 2p and O 1s between G10 and pure samples, respectively.The C 1s spectrum of pure g-C 3 N 4 has two obvious peaks at binding energies of 284.7 and 287.7 eV.The peak at a binding energy of 284.7 eV can be attributed to the adventitious carbon impurities, whereas the peak at 287.7 eV can be assigned to the sp 2 -hybridized carbon atoms in aromatic rings of g-C 3 N 4 .Two similar peaks were also observed in the spectra of G10 at binding energies of 284.5 and 287.4 eV, which shied towards the lower energy region by 0.2 and 0.3 eV, respectively.The N 1s spectrum of pure g-C 3 N 4 shows two clear peaks at binding energies of 398.3 and 400.2 eV, p-excitations.Similar strong peaks at 398.0 and 400.3 eV were also observed in the N 1s spectra of G10, indicating the existence of the g-C 3 N 4 phase.The Zn 2p spectrum of the pure ZnO demonstrates 1047.4 eV, showing that the original doublet peak splits up into a quartet peak in total.The doublet peak at 1020.9 and 1044.1 eV is attributed to Zn atoms within the ZnO phase, while the other N 4 phase and ZnO phase.Furthermore, compared with pure ZnO, the O 1s states of G10 were observed to shi into the higher energy region.Considering only the interfacial Zn atoms, the binding energy of The photocatalytic activity of various samples for CO 2 reduction was evaluated under simulated solar irradiation in the anaerobic environment.Control experiments were performed in the absence of either light illumination or photocatalysts and no appreciable amounts of any hydrocarbon products were found, conrming that light irradiation and photocatalysts are the two essential factors for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction reactions.In this work, the gaseous CO 2 introduced by the in situ reaction between sodium bicarbonate and hydrochloride aqueous solution serves as the only carbon source and the water vapor can also be generated by the reaction.The nal products of G10 and pure g-C 3 N 4 detected by gas chromatography (GC) are shown in Fig. 9.As seen in Fig. 9, CH 3 OH was the only product detected by the GC FID method for both the G10 sample and pure g-C 3 N 4 .Typically, photocatalytic CO 2 reduction is a complex multielectron transfer process, which has the potential to give rise to more than one reduced species including CH 4 , CH 3 OH, HCOOH and HCHO.However, no products other than CH 3 OH were observed for all the as-prepared samples, indicating that both the synthesized pure g-C 3 N 4 and G10 samples exhibit good reaction selectivity to convert CO 2 directly into CH 3 OH under solar irradiation.Although the underlying mechanism of photocatalytic CO 2 reduction still remains ambiguous until now, there are three possible reasons regarding why CH 3 OH was the only product detected in our experiments: (1) as mentioned above, the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction reaction took place at the solid-gas interface and the products were determined by the extracted gas samples under our experimental conditions.If HCOOH and HCHO were indeed produced upon light irradiation, they were more likely to adsorb on the surfaces of samples than CH 3 OH, due to the stronger polarity of HCOOH and HCHO.Thus, only CH 3 OH could easily desorb into the gas phase aer the reaction and then be detected by the GC FID method; (2) as is well known, HCOOH and HCHO are relatively unstable molecules compared with CH 3 OH, which can be readily re-oxidized into CO 2 by the oxygen gas generated during the reaction process; (3) comparatively speaking, the production of CH 4 from photocatalytic CO 2 reduction requires more electrons (8e A ) and protons (8H ) in contrast to CH 3 OH (6e A and 6H ).In this regard, the specic reaction routes and the nal products can be closely associated with the intrinsic properties of the photocatalysts.It is worth mentioning that such most desirable value-added fuels that are easy to store and utilize, while the good selectivity of CH 3 OH generation can also effectively facilitate the subsequent product separation process. To investigate the thermostability and measure the g-C 3 N 4 contents in G10, TGA analyses were performed on both the obtained G10 and pure samples, from ambient temperature to 900 C at a heating rate of 10 C min A1 .The corresponding results are shown in Fig. 2. For the pure g-C 3 N 4 , the rapid decay of the TGA curve from around 450 C to 600 C represents the typical thermal decomposition of g-C 3 N 4 , indicating its intrinsic thermal instability in this temperature range.No signicant weight loss is observed in the TGA curve of pure ZnO, con-rming the high thermal stability of ZnO.Compared with pure g-C 3 N 4 , the TGA curve decay of the G10 sample starts and ends at lower temperatures, respectively.This suggests that the obtained G10 sample demonstrates lower thermal stability upon heating than the pure g-C 3 N 4 , which is mainly due to the disturbance of simultaneous ZnO crystallization towards interlayer stacking motifs of g-C 3 N 4 or the catalyzing effect of ZnO over g-C 3 N 4 thermal decomposition.A similar phenomenon was also observed in other cases such as g-C 3 N 4 /TiO 2 coupling. 44he relative content of the ZnO phase in the G10 sample is determined to be 44.6,accounting for nearly half the weight composition of G10.Considering the original mass ratio of the precursors of g-C 3 N 4 (urea) and ZnO (zinc nitrate hexahydrate) to be around 10, a signicant amount of urea is estimated to undergo direct thermal decomposition into gases during polycondensation, 45 because the holding temperature of condensation is precisely within the above measured temperature range for pure g-C 3 N 4 decomposition. XPS analyses were performed to investigate the chemical composition and elucidate the elemental chemical states of all samples.As expected, there are four major elemental states detected in the prepared G10 samples, namely C 1s, N 1s, Zn 2p and O 1s.Fig. 3a-d present the comparison of the high-resolution XPS spectra of C 1s, N 1s, Zn 2p and O 1s between G10 and pure samples, respectively.The C 1s spectrum of pure g-C 3 N 4 has two obvious peaks at binding energies of 284.7 and 287.7 eV.The peak at a binding energy of 284.7 eV can be attributed to the adventitious carbon impurities, whereas the peak at 287.7 eV can be assigned to the sp 2 -hybridized carbon atoms in aromatic rings of g-C 3 N 4 .Two similar peaks were also observed in the spectra of G10 at binding energies of 284.5 and 287.4 eV, which shied towards the lower energy region by 0.2 and 0.3 eV, respectively.The N 1s spectrum of pure g-C 3 N 4 shows two clear peaks at binding energies of 398.3 and 400.2 eV, which can be ascribed to sp 2 -hybridized nitrogen atoms involved in triazine (CN-C) units and amino groups (C-N-H), respectively.Moreover, the weak shoulder peak at 404.2 eV accounts for p-excitations.Similar strong peaks at 398.0 and 400.3 eV were also observed in the N 1s spectra of G10, indicating the existence of the g-C 3 N 4 phase.The Zn 2p spectrum of the pure ZnO demonstrates 1047.4 eV, showing that the original doublet peak splits up into a quartet peak in total.The doublet peak at 1020.9 and 1044.1 eV is attributed to Zn atoms within the ZnO phase, while the other N 4 phase and ZnO phase.Furthermore, compared with pure ZnO, the O 1s states of G10 were observed to shi into the higher energy region.Considering only the interfacial Zn atoms, the binding energy of Zn 2p states of G10 also increased in contrast to pure ZnO.Since the binding energy of C 1s and N 1s states of G10 generally decreased compared with pure g-C 3 N 4 , the ZnO and g-C 3 N 4 phases of G10 exhibit opposite tendency of binding energy shis relative to the pure samples.This opposite tendency suggests that the total electron density shis from the ZnO phase to the g-C 3 N 4 phase and thus causes the formation of N-Zn-O covalent bonds between two phases, mainly due to the backbonding ability of the fully occupied Zn 3d orbitals and the electron dispersive capacity of C-N p-p conjugated structures.The formation of interfacial covalent bonds indicates the intimate contact between the ZnO phase and g-C 3 N 4 phase, which is also benecial for the formation of the direct Z-scheme g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO binary composite photocatalytic system, thus facilitating the transfer and separation of charge carriers and further promoting the enhancement of photocatalytic activity. 404 The electronic structures of both pure g-C 3 N 4 and the G10 sample were evaluated by UV-vis diffuse reectance spectroscopy.As seen in Fig. 7, for pure g-C 3 N 4 , a sharp increase of light absorption occurs at wavelengths shorter than 450 nm, which can be attributed to the intrinsic band gap of g-C 3 N 4 .As denoted by the dashed line, the absorption edge of g-C 3 N 4 at about 450 nm corresponds to a typical band gap of 2.7 eV, which is consistent with the values reported in other literature studies. 26ompared with the pure g-C 3 N 4 , the as-prepared G10 sample exhibits stronger light absorption in both ultraviolet and visible light regions.The increased absorption of ultraviolet light can be attributed to the existence of the ZnO phase in the sample.The enhancement of visible light absorption can stem from more defect states in the g-C 3 N 4 phase that are introduced by the interference of simultaneous ZnO crystallization towards g-C 3 N 4 condensation.Such extended absorption of visible light originated from the effect of introduced defect states is also observed in other reports. 33In general, the G10 sample has stronger absorption in the whole spectrum and can absorb more solar energy for photocatalytic reactions.Thus, it is not surprising that G10 has better sunlight utilization and higher photocatalytic activity than the pure g-C 3 N 4 . The photocatalytic activity of various samples for CO 2 reduction was evaluated under simulated solar irradiation in the anaerobic environment.Control experiments were performed in the absence of either light illumination or photocatalysts and no appreciable amounts of any hydrocarbon products were found, conrming that light irradiation and photocatalysts are the two essential factors for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction reactions.In this work, the gaseous CO 2 introduced by the in situ reaction between sodium bicarbonate and hydrochloride aqueous solution serves as the only carbon source and the water vapor can also be generated by the reaction.The nal products of G10 and pure g-C 3 N 4 detected by gas chromatography (GC) are shown in Fig. 9.As seen in Fig. 9, CH 3 OH was the only product detected by the GC FID method for both the G10 sample and pure g-C 3 N 4 .Typically, photocatalytic CO 2 reduction is a complex multielectron transfer process, which has the potential to give rise to more than one reduced species including CH 4 , CH 3 OH, HCOOH and HCHO.However, no products other than CH 3 OH were observed for all the as-prepared samples, indicating that both the synthesized pure g-C 3 N 4 and G10 samples exhibit good reaction selectivity to convert CO 2 directly into CH 3 OH under solar irradiation.Although the underlying mechanism of photocatalytic CO 2 reduction still remains ambiguous until now, there are three possible reasons regarding why CH 3 OH was the only product detected in our experiments: (1) as mentioned above, the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction reaction took place at the solid-gas interface and the products were determined by the extracted gas samples under our experimental conditions.If HCOOH and HCHO were indeed produced upon light irradiation, they were more likely to adsorb on the surfaces of samples than CH 3 OH, due to the stronger polarity of HCOOH and HCHO.Thus, only CH 3 OH could easily desorb into the gas phase aer the reaction and then be detected by the GC FID method; (2) as is well known, HCOOH and HCHO are relatively unstable molecules compared with CH 3 OH, which can be readily re-oxidized into CO 2 by the oxygen gas generated during the reaction process; (3) comparatively speaking, the production of CH 4 from photocatalytic CO 2 reduction requires more electrons (8e A ) and protons (8H ) in contrast to CH 3 OH (6e A and 6H ).In this regard, the specic reaction routes and the nal products can be closely associated with the intrinsic properties of the photocatalysts.It is worth mentioning that such good conversion selectivity of g-C 3 N 4 for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction into CH 3 OH rather than CH 4 was also conrmed by results from other groups. 50,51As is well known, CH 3 OH is one of the most desirable value-added fuels that are easy to store and utilize, while the good selectivity of CH 3 OH generation can also effectively facilitate the subsequent product separation process. The specic CH 3 OH production rates of various samples were calculated from the GC spectra based on the integral area between each peak and baseline.Fig. 10 presents the comparison of CH 3 OH production rates of the commercial ZnO, the prepared pure ZnO, G10 and pure g-C 3 N 4 samples.The CH 3 OH production rate of the obtained pure ZnO (0.37 mmol h A1 g A1 ) is comparable to that of the commercial ZnO (0.32 mmol h A1 g A1 ), showing the considerable photocatalytic activity of single-phase ZnO by utilizing UV light.Despite the high specic surface area and the large pore volume of g-C 3 N 4 , its CH 3 OH production rate (0.26 mmol h A1 g A1 ) still remains relatively low, mainly due to the high recombination rates of photogenerated electrons and holes.However, compared with both the pure g-C 3 N 4 and pure ZnO, the obtained G10 sample exhibits the highest CH 3 OH production rate (0.6 mmol h A1 g A1 ).On the basis of the results in Table 1, the specic surface area of G10 (12.8 m 2 g A1 ) is drastically reduced in contrast to the pure g-C 3 N 4 (48.5 m 2 g A1 ), possibly because of the intercalated ZnO crystallization within the original pores in the g-C 3 N 4 phase.Although the specic surface area is critical for heterogenous catalysis, the higher production rate of the G10 sample with a lower specic surface area suggests highly efficient charge carrier separation occurring at the g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO interface.Combined with the previous analyses of surface area and microstructure observation, the Fig. 8 FT-IR spectra of G10 (red) and pure g-C 3 N 4 (black). In general, there are two possible mechanisms accounting for the photocatalytic activity enhancement induced by spatial separation of photogenerated charge carriers in binary photocatalytic systems: (1) conventional heterojunction-type and (2) direct Z-scheme type. 52In order to facilitate analyses, schematic comparison regarding band edge positions of g-C 3 N 4 and ZnO together with the standard potentials of relevant redox couples is presented in Fig. 11.As seen in Fig. 11, the energy potentials of conduction bands (CB) of g-C 3 N 4 (A1.12V vs. NHE) and ZnO (A0.2 V vs. NHE) are both more negative than the standard potential of the CO 2 /CH 3 OH redox couple (0.03 V vs. NHE), while the energy potentials of valence bands (VB) of g-C 3 N 4 (1.57V vs. NHE) and ZnO (3.0 V vs. NHE) are both more positive than the standard potential of the O 2 /H 2 O redox couple (1.23 V vs. NHE).In this regard, both the above two mechanisms can be possible in explaining the enhanced photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activity of the g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO binary photocatalytic system.Schematic diagrams illustrating the detailed processes of the above two possible mechanisms in the g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO photocatalytic system are demonstrated in Fig. 12.In the heterojunction-type photocatalytic system presented in Fig. 12a, the excited electrons transfer from the CB of g-C 3 N 4 with higher energy potentials to the CB of ZnO with lower energy potentials, resulting in the decrease of electron reducibility.Thus, in this case, it should be the electrons from the CB of ZnO reducing CO 2 into CH 3 OH.Meanwhile, the photogenerated holes transfer from the VB of ZnO to the VB of g-C 3 N 4 , which also results in the decrease of hole oxidizability.The other type is the direct Z-scheme photocatalytic system shown in Fig. 12b.Upon simultaneous light excitation, both g-C 3 N 4 and ZnO phases can generate excited electron-hole pairs.The excited electrons from the CB of ZnO with lower energy can transfer to combine with the photogenerated holes in g-C 3 N 4 , thus preserving the electrons with stronger reducibility in the CB of g-C 3 N 4 and holes with stronger oxidizability in the VB of ZnO.Finally, the electrons from the CB of g-C 3 N 4 can react with CO 2 and produce CH 3 OH.In this regard, it should be noted that the interfacial electron transfer actually occurs in opposite directions for the heterojunction-type (g-C 3 N 4 to ZnO) and direct Z-scheme type (ZnO to g-C 3 N 4 ) photocatalytic systems. 16n order to provide clues to understand the underlying mechanism responsible for the direct Z-scheme mechanism (see Fig. 12b), the photogenerated electrons and holes will be respectively preserved in the CB of g-C 3 N 4 and the VB of ZnO, maintaining enough reducibility and oxidizability to produce superoxide anion radicals (O 2 A ) and hydroxyl radicals (OH) respectively. The experimental measurement of hydroxyl radicals (OH) also showed that the PL signals of the G10 sample increased almost linearly with irradiation time, whose intensity is more comparable to that of pure ZnO.The presence of PL signals of the G10 samples conrmed that the hydroxyl radicals (OH) were indeed produced on the surface of G10 upon light illumination either in the direct or indirect pathway. 53On the basis of the above PL analyses, the binary g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO composite photocatalytic system is more likely to follow a direct Z-scheme photocatalytic mechanism, rather than the conventional heterojunction-type photocatalytic mechanism. To further investigate the specic mechanism accounting for the enhanced photocatalytic activity of the G10 sample, the transient photocurrent responses of both pure g-C 3 N 4 and G10 were recorded by using typical switch on-off cycles of light irradiation.In this work, we adopted two light sources with different wavelengths (365 and 420 nm) to carry out the photocurrent measurements to probe the excitation, transfer, separation and recombination of photogenerated charge carriers.Typically, the value of photocurrent density corresponds to the charge collection efficiency and a higher value of the photocurrent response generally means higher separation efficiency of photogenerated electrons and holes.Fig. 14 shows the comparison of photocurrent-time (I-t) curves of G10 and pure g-C 3 N 4 catalyst.context: In summary, a direct Z-scheme g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO binary composite photocatalytic system was successfully constructed via a onestep facile calcination method utilizing affordable urea and zinc nitrate hexahydrate as precursors.The characterization results show that simultaneous ZnO crystallization takes place within the original pores of g-C 3 N 4 during urea polycondensation, thus leading to two separate phases with intimate interfacial contact.The g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO photocatalytic system exhibits stronger and extended light absorption in the visible light range than pure g-C 3 N 4 , which is due to more defect states in the g-C 3 N 4 phase introduced by the interference of ZnO crystallization.Also, the g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO photocatalyst demonstrates 2.3 times higher photocatalytic activity for CO 2 reduction into CH 3 OH with preserved reaction selectivity compared with pure g-C 3 N 4 .The overall enhancement of photoactivity of the g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO binary photocatalytic system is attributed to a direct Z-scheme mechanism rather than the conventional heterojunction-type mechanism, which is further conrmed by PL analyses of hydroxyl radicals, photocurrent measurements and DFT calculations of charge carrier effective mass.Considering the improved photoactivity and maintained reaction selectivity of the g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO system, this work will not only illustrate the coupling effect of ZnO on the enhanced photocatalytic activity of g-C 3 N 4 via a direct Z-scheme mechanism, but also provide unprecedented insights into the further construction of direct Z-scheme photocatalytic systems without an electron mediator for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction reactions. catalyst.context: In summary, a direct Z-scheme g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO binary composite photocatalytic system was successfully constructed via a onestep facile calcination method utilizing affordable urea and zinc nitrate hexahydrate as precursors.The characterization results show that simultaneous ZnO crystallization takes place within the original pores of g-C 3 N 4 during urea polycondensation, thus leading to two separate phases with intimate interfacial contact.The g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO photocatalytic system exhibits stronger and extended light absorption in the visible light range than pure g-C 3 N 4 , which is due to more defect states in the g-C 3 N 4 phase introduced by the interference of ZnO crystallization.Also, the g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO photocatalyst demonstrates 2.3 times higher photocatalytic activity for CO 2 reduction into CH 3 OH with preserved reaction selectivity compared with pure g-C 3 N 4 .The overall enhancement of photoactivity of the g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO binary photocatalytic system is attributed to a direct Z-scheme mechanism rather than the conventional heterojunction-type mechanism, which is further conrmed by PL analyses of hydroxyl radicals, photocurrent measurements and DFT calculations of charge carrier effective mass.Considering the improved photoactivity and maintained reaction selectivity of the g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO system, this work will not only illustrate the coupling effect of ZnO on the enhanced photocatalytic activity of g-C 3 N 4 via a direct Z-scheme mechanism, but also provide unprecedented insights into the further construction of direct Z-scheme photocatalytic systems without an electron mediator for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction reactions. light source.context: All chemicals were of analytical grade and used without further purication.Urea and zinc nitrate hexahydrate were used as the precursors for the synthesis of g-C 3 N 4 and ZnO, respectively.In a typical run, 10.0 g of urea was rst dispersed in 20 mL of deionized water with the addition of 1.0 g of zinc nitrate hexahydrate.Aer the obtained solution was vigorously stirred for 30 min, it was then put in an incubator at 80 C until the remaining water was all removed.Then the resultant white solids in an alumina crucible with a cover were put in a muffle furnace and the precursors were heated to 550 C for 2 h with a heating rate of around 10 C min A1 .When cooled to room temperature, the yellow solid was collected and ground to ne powders.The obtained g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO composite was labeled as G10 for simplicity, where 10 represented the relative weight ratio of urea to zinc nitrate hexahydrate.For the purpose of comparison, both the pure g-C 3 N 4 and pure ZnO were also prepared via the same synthetic route and conditions. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a D/Max-RB X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan), under Cu Ka radiation at a scan rate (2q) of 0.05 s A1 .The accelerating voltage and applied current were 40 kV and 80 mA, respectively.The thermal properties of the obtained samples were investigated using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) with a DTG-60H analyzer (Shimadzu Corp., Tokyo, Japan).About 5 mg of each sample was heated from ambient temperature to 900 C at a heating rate of 10 C min A1 .X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed using an ultra-high-vacuum VG ESCA-LAB 210 electron spectrometer equipped with a multi-channel detector.The spectrum was excited by Mg Ka radiation of two anodes in the constant analyzer energy mode and operating at 200 W.All the binding energies were referenced to the C 1s peak at 285.0 eV of the surface adventitious carbon.Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) images were obtained by using a JSM-7500F (JEOL, Japan) scanning electron microscope.Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high resolution TEM (HRTEM) analyses were conducted on a Tecnai G 2 F20 S-TWIN microscope at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV.UV-visible absorbance spectra were obtained by using the diepressed disk sample and a UV-visible spectrophotometer (UV-2550, SHIMADZU, Japan), in which BaSO 4 was used as the reectance standard.Fourier transform infrared spectra (FTIR) of the samples were evaluated using an IR Affiinity-1 FTIR spectrometer that used conventional KBr pellets in the range of 4000-500 cm A1 at room temperature.Nitrogen adsorptiondesorption isotherms were measured on an ASAP 2020 nitrogen adsorption apparatus (Micromeritics, USA).All of the samples were degassed at 180 C before measurements.The BET surface area was determined by a multipoint BET method using the adsorption data in the relative pressure (P/P 0 ) range of 0.05-0.25.The pore size distributions were determined using desorption data by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method.Photoluminescence (PL) emission spectra were used to investigate the hydroxyl radicals produced on the surface of all samples upon light irradiation in the presence of 5 A 10 A4 M terephthalic acid in 2 A 10 A3 M NaOH solution, and were measured at room temperature on an F-7000 Fluorescence Spectrophotometer (Hitachi, Japan).The excitation wavelength was 315 nm, the scanning speed was 1200 nm min A1 and the photomultiplier tube (PMT) voltage was 700 V.The width of both the excitation slit and the emission slit was 2.5 nm. The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 was performed in a 200 mL homemade Pyrex reactor at ambient temperature and atmospheric pressure.The reactor has two openings that were sealed using a silicone rubber septum.Typically, 100 mg of the sample was dispersed in the added 10 mL of deionized water by ultrasonication for about 30 min to form a suspension.Aer evaporation of water at 80 C, the catalyst was deposited at the bottom of the reactor to form thin lms.Before irradiation, the reactor was blown with nitrogen for 30 min to remove air and ensure that the reaction system was under anaerobic conditions.CO 2 and H 2 O vapor were in situ produced by the reaction of NaHCO 3 (0.12 g, introduced into the reactor before sealing) and HCl aqueous solution (0.25 mL, 4 M) that was injected into the reactor via a syringe.A 300 W simulated solar Xe arc lamp (Changzhou Siyu Science Co. Ltd, China) was used as the light source and positioned around 10 cm vertically above the photocatalytic reactor. 1 mL of gas products was taken from the reactor aer 1 h irradiation and used for gas component analysis by using a gas chromatograph (GC-2014C, Shimadzu, Japan) equipped with a ame ionized detector (FID) and a methanizer.The products were calibrated with a standard gas mixture and determined by the retention time.Nitrogen of high purity was used in the GC-2014C as carrier gas.Blank experiments were carried out in the absence of CO 2 or light irradiation to conrm that CO 2 and light were two indispensable factors for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction reactions. Photocurrent measurements were performed on a CHI 660D electrochemical workstation (Chenhua Instrument, Shanghai, China) in a conventional three-electrode conguration including a working electrode, counter electrode and reference electrode.The working electrode prepared with the sample has an active area of ca.0.5 cm 2 .A Pt wire and Ag/AgCl electrode (immersed in saturated KCl solution) were used as the counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively.Two different low power LEDs (3 W, 365 and 420 nm) (Shenzhen LAMPLIC Science Co. Ltd China) were used as the light source with a focused intensity of ca.80.0 mW cm A2 . 1 M Na 2 SO 4 aqueous solution was used as the electrolyte in the photocurrent measurement.Typically, the working electrodes were prepared as follows: 0.2 g of the asprepared photocatalyst was mixed with 0.08 g of polyethylene glycol (PEG, molecular weight: 20 000) and 2 mL of water, and then the mixture was ground to form a slurry.Next, the slurry was coated onto a pre-cleaned 2 cm A 1.2 cm F-doped SnO 2coated glass (FTO glass) electrode via a doctor blade technique.The prepared electrodes were dried and then calcined at 450 C for 30 min in an oven with a heating rate of 5 C min A1 . The rst-principle DFT calculations performed on a CASTEP code based on the plane-wave pseudopotential method were used to investigate the charge carrier effective masses of ZnO and g-C 3 N 4 .The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) was used as the exchangecorrelation function.The ultraso pseudopotential was used to describe the interaction between the ionic core and valence electrons.The lattice parameters and atomic coordinates were relaxed using a cutoff energy of 380 eV and Monkhorst-pack grids of 4 A 4 A 2 k-points for both ZnO and g-C 3 N 4 models.Geometric optimization was rst achieved using convergence thresholds of 2 A 10 A5 eV per atom for total energy, 0.03 eV AA1 for maximum force, 0.05 GPa for pressure, and 0.001 A for maximum displacement.The self-consistent calculations were performed with a total tolerance of less than 1 A 10 A6 eV per atom.Aer the geometric optimizations were nished, the band structures of ZnO and g-C 3 N 4 were obtained and the effective masses of charge carriers were calculated based on the obtained electronic structures.

0.326 nm.The weaker (001) peak at around 13.1 with a distance of 0.675 nm can be ascribed to interlayer planar stacking motifs.These two characteristic peaks of pure g-C 3 N 4 are consistent with the The photocatalytic activity of various samples for CO 2 reduction was evaluated under simulated solar irradiation in the anaerobic environment.Control experiments were performed in the absence of either light illumination or photocatalysts and no appreciable amounts of any hydrocarbon products were found, conrming that light irradiation and photocatalysts are the two essential factors for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction reactions.In this work, the gaseous CO 2 introduced by the in situ reaction between sodium bicarbonate and hydrochloride aqueous solution serves as the only carbon source and the water vapor can also be generated by the reaction.The nal products of G10 and pure g-C 3 N 4 detected by gas chromatography (GC) are shown in Fig. 9.As seen in Fig. 9, CH 3 OH was the only product detected by the GC FID method for both the G10 sample and pure g-C 3 N 4 .Typically, photocatalytic CO 2 reduction is a complex multielectron transfer process, which has the potential to give rise to more than one reduced species including CH 4 , CH 3 OH, HCOOH and HCHO.However, no products other than CH 3 OH were observed for all the as-prepared samples, indicating that both the synthesized pure g-C 3 N 4 and G10 samples exhibit good reaction selectivity to convert CO 2 directly into CH 3 OH under solar irradiation.Although the underlying mechanism of photocatalytic CO 2 reduction still remains ambiguous until now, there are three possible reasons regarding why CH 3 OH was the only product detected in our experiments: (1) as mentioned above, the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction reaction took place at the solid-gas interface and the products were determined by the extracted gas samples under our experimental conditions.If HCOOH and HCHO were indeed produced upon light irradiation, they were more likely to adsorb on the surfaces of samples than CH 3 OH, due to the stronger polarity of HCOOH and HCHO.Thus, only CH 3 OH could easily desorb into the gas phase aer the reaction and then be detected by the GC FID method; (2) as is well known, HCOOH and HCHO are relatively unstable molecules compared with CH 3 OH, which can be readily re-oxidized into CO 2 by the oxygen gas generated during the reaction process; (3) comparatively speaking, the production of CH 4 from photocatalytic CO 2 reduction requires more electrons (8e A ) and protons (8H ) in contrast to CH 3 OH (6e A and 6H ).In this regard, the specic reaction routes and the nal products can be closely associated with the intrinsic properties of the photocatalysts.It is worth mentioning that such good conversion selectivity of g-C 3 N 4 for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction into CH 3 OH rather than CH 4 was also conrmed by results from other groups. 50,51As is well known, CH 3 OH is one of the most desirable value-added fuels that are easy to store and utilize, while the good selectivity of CH 3 OH generation can also effectively facilitate the subsequent product separation process. The specic CH 3 OH production rates of various samples were calculated from the GC spectra based on the integral area between each peak and baseline.Fig. 10 presents the comparison of CH 3 OH production rates of the commercial ZnO, the prepared pure ZnO, G10 and pure g-C 3 N 4 samples.The CH 3 OH production rate of the obtained pure ZnO (0.37 mmol h A1 g A1 ) is comparable to that of the commercial ZnO (0.32 mmol h A1 g A1 ), showing the considerable photocatalytic activity of single-phase ZnO by utilizing UV light.Despite the high specic surface area and the large pore volume of g-C 3 N 4 , its CH 3 OH production rate (0.26 mmol h A1 g A1 ) still remains relatively low, mainly due to the high recombination rates of photogenerated electrons and holes.However, compared with both the pure g-C 3 N 4 and pure ZnO, the obtained G10 sample exhibits the highest CH 3 OH production rate (0.6 mmol h A1 g A1 ).On the basis of the results in Table 1, the specic surface area of G10 (12.8 m 2 g A1 ) is drastically reduced in contrast to the pure g-C 3 N 4 (48.5 m 2 g A1 ), possibly because of the intercalated ZnO crystallization within the original pores in the g-C 3 N 4 phase.Although the specic surface area is critical for heterogenous catalysis, the higher production rate of the G10 sample with a lower specic surface area suggests highly efficient charge carrier separation occurring at the g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO interface.Combined with the previous analyses of surface area and microstructure observation, the Fig. 8 FT-IR spectra of G10 (red) and pure g-C 3 N 4 (black). Fig. 9 GC spectra of G10 (red) and pure g-C 3 N 4 (black). intimate interfacial contact between the two phases is benecial for the separation of excited charge carriers, the inhibition of unfavorable recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs and the further promotion of the photocatalytic activity.In this regard, by coupling ZnO with g-C 3 N 4 via a facile approach, we achieved an enhanced photocatalytic reduction rate of CO 2 into CH 3 OH for pure g-C 3 N 4 by a factor of 2.3, while preserving the original reaction selectivity to directly convert CO 2 into CH 3 OH. In general, there are two possible mechanisms accounting for the photocatalytic activity enhancement induced by spatial separation of photogenerated charge carriers in binary photocatalytic systems: (1) conventional heterojunction-type and (2) direct Z-scheme type. 52In order to facilitate analyses, schematic comparison regarding band edge positions of g-C 3 N 4 and ZnO together with the standard potentials of relevant redox couples is presented in Fig. 11.As seen in Fig. 11, the energy potentials of conduction bands (CB) of g-C 3 N 4 (A1.12V vs. NHE) and ZnO (A0.2 V vs. NHE) are both more negative than the standard potential of the CO 2 /CH 3 OH redox couple (0.03 V vs. NHE), while the energy potentials of valence bands (VB) of g-C 3 N 4 (1.57V vs. NHE) and ZnO (3.0 V vs. NHE) are both more positive than the standard potential of the O 2 /H 2 O redox couple (1.23 V vs. NHE).In this regard, both the above two mechanisms can be possible in explaining the enhanced photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activity of the g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO binary photocatalytic system.Schematic diagrams illustrating the detailed processes of the above two possible mechanisms in the g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO photocatalytic system are demonstrated in Fig. 12.In the heterojunction-type photocatalytic system presented in Fig. 12a, the excited electrons transfer from the CB of g-C 3 N 4 with higher energy potentials to the CB of ZnO with lower energy potentials, resulting in the decrease of electron reducibility.Thus, in this case, it should be the electrons from the CB of ZnO reducing CO 2 into CH 3 OH.Meanwhile, the photogenerated holes transfer from the VB of ZnO to the VB of g-C 3 N 4 , which also results in the decrease of hole oxidizability.The other type is the direct Z-scheme photocatalytic system shown in reaction medium.context: XRD patterns were recorded in Fig. 1 to reveal the phase structure of the g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO photocatalytic system (G10).For the purpose of comparison, XRD patterns of both pure g-C 3 N 4 and pure ZnO obtained through the same preparation method are also shown in Fig. 1.The XRD patterns of the pure g-C 3 N 4 exhibit two pronounced diffraction peaks that were found at 27.4 and 13.1 , respectively.The stronger peak at 27.4 which is attributed to the interlayer stacking of aromatic systems can be indexed to the (002) crystal plane and corresponds to an interlayer distance of 0.326 nm.The weaker (001) peak at around 13.1 with a distance of 0.675 nm can be ascribed to interlayer planar stacking motifs.These two characteristic peaks of pure g-C 3 N 4 are consistent with the previous results. 18,26,33The prepared pure ZnO demonstrates characteristic diffraction peaks with high intensities of the wurtzite hexagonal ZnO phase, which is the most stable and common form of ZnO under ambient conditions.The XRD pattern of the pure ZnO indicates that the wurtzite hexagonal ZnO crystals with high crystallinity can form under the synthetic conditions, which stems from the decomposition of zinc nitrate hexahydrate.For the obtained G10 sample, nearly all of the characteristic diffraction peaks of wurtzite hexagonal ZnO were clearly shown in its XRD pattern without any noticeable shis of diffraction angles (2q), conrming the existence of the ZnO phase.As for the g-C 3 N 4 phase, only the (002) peak of g-C 3 N 4 was obscurely observed whose diffraction intensity was lower compared with that of the ZnO phase.The relatively poor crystallinity of the g-C 3 N 4 phase indicates that the simultaneous crystallization of the ZnO phase interferes with the condensation process and interlayer stacking patterns of the g-C 3 N 4 phase, thus resulting in its weak diffraction intensity.The XRD patterns of both the ZnO phase and g-C 3 N 4 phase in the G10 sample suggest that these two phases exist separately in the composite and no strong crystal lattice incorporation is observed between these two phases. To investigate the thermostability and measure the g-C 3 N 4 contents in G10, TGA analyses were performed on both the obtained G10 and pure samples, from ambient temperature to 900 C at a heating rate of 10 C min A1 .The corresponding results are shown in Fig. 2. For the pure g-C 3 N 4 , the rapid decay of the TGA curve from around 450 C to 600 C represents the typical thermal decomposition of g-C 3 N 4 , indicating its intrinsic thermal instability in this temperature range.No signicant weight loss is observed in the TGA curve of pure ZnO, con-rming the high thermal stability of ZnO.Compared with pure g-C 3 N 4 , the TGA curve decay of the G10 sample starts and ends at lower temperatures, respectively.This suggests that the obtained G10 sample demonstrates lower thermal stability upon heating than the pure g-C 3 N 4 , which is mainly due to the disturbance of simultaneous ZnO crystallization towards interlayer stacking motifs of g-C 3 N 4 or the catalyzing effect of ZnO over g-C 3 N 4 thermal decomposition.A similar phenomenon was also observed in other cases such as g-C 3 N 4 /TiO 2 coupling. 44he relative content of the ZnO phase in the G10 sample is determined to be 44.6,accounting for nearly half the weight composition of G10.Considering the original mass ratio of the precursors of g-C 3 N 4 (urea) and ZnO (zinc nitrate hexahydrate) to be around 10, a signicant amount of urea is estimated to undergo direct thermal decomposition into gases during polycondensation, 45 because the holding temperature of condensation is precisely within the above measured temperature range for pure g-C 3 N 4 decomposition. XPS analyses were performed to investigate the chemical composition and elucidate the elemental chemical states of all samples.As expected, there are four major elemental states detected in the prepared G10 samples, namely C 1s, N 1s, Zn 2p and O 1s.Fig. 3a-d present the comparison of the high-resolution XPS spectra of C 1s, N 1s, Zn 2p and O 1s between G10 and pure samples, respectively.The C 1s spectrum of pure g-C 3 N 4 has two obvious peaks at binding energies of 284.7 and 287.7 eV.The peak at a binding energy of 284.7 eV can be attributed to the adventitious carbon impurities, whereas the peak at 287.7 eV can be assigned to the sp 2 -hybridized carbon atoms in aromatic rings of g-C 3 N 4 .Two similar peaks were also observed in the spectra of G10 at binding energies of 284.5 and 287.4 eV, which shied towards the lower energy region by 0.2 and 0.3 eV, respectively.The N 1s spectrum of pure g-C 3 N 4 shows two clear peaks at binding energies of 398.3 and 400.2 eV, which can be ascribed to sp 2 -hybridized nitrogen atoms involved in triazine (CN-C) units and amino groups (C-N-H), respectively.Moreover, the weak shoulder peak at 404.2 eV accounts for p-excitations.Similar strong peaks at 398.0 and 400.3 eV were also observed in the N 1s spectra of G10, indicating the existence of the g-C 3 N 4 phase.The Zn 2p spectrum of the pure ZnO demonstrates a doublet at binding energies of 1021.3 and 1044.5 eV, assigned to Zn 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 states, respectively.The corresponding peaks of Zn 2p in the G10 spectra appear at 1020.9, 1023, 1044.1 and 1047.4 eV, showing that the original doublet peak splits up into a quartet peak in total.The doublet peak at 1020.9 and 1044.1 eV is attributed to Zn atoms within the ZnO phase, while the other doublet peak at 1023 and 1047.4 eV is ascribed to Zn atoms at the g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO interface.The splitting of the original doublet peak indicates the possible interfacial hybridization between the g-C 3 N 4 phase and ZnO phase.Furthermore, compared with pure ZnO, the O 1s states of G10 were observed to shi into the higher energy region.Considering only the interfacial Zn atoms, the binding energy of Zn 2p states of G10 also increased in contrast to pure ZnO.Since the binding energy of C 1s and N 1s states of G10 generally decreased compared with pure g-C 3 N 4 , the ZnO and g-C 3 N 4 phases of G10 exhibit opposite tendency of binding energy shis relative to the pure samples.This opposite tendency suggests that the total electron density shis from the ZnO phase to the g-C 3 N 4 phase and thus causes the formation of N-Zn-O covalent bonds between two phases, mainly due to the backbonding ability of the fully occupied Zn 3d orbitals and the electron dispersive capacity of C-N p-p conjugated structures.The formation of interfacial covalent bonds indicates the intimate contact between the ZnO phase and g-C 3 N 4 phase, which is also benecial for the formation of the direct Z-scheme g-C 3 N 4 /ZnO binary composite photocatalytic system, thus facilitating the transfer and separation of charge carriers and further promoting the enhancement of photocatalytic activity. 404 Microstructure observation SEM and TEM images were further used to investigate the microstructure and morphology of all the prepared samples.Fig. 4a presents the typical large ZnO microcrystals obtained under the above mentioned synthetic conditions whose sizes have reached tens of micrometers.These microcrystals generally demonstrate well-dened crystal facets, corresponding to their high crystallinity reected by XRD patterns.Fig. 4b andc show the representative highly porous structure of pure g-C 3 N 4 derived from urea, formed by considerable gas release during thermal condensation.45 Fig. 4d and e display the morphology of the obtained G10 sample, which has much more compact structures compared with pure g-C 3 N 4 .Such elimination of high porosity and the transformation into more compact structures are mainly due to the imbedded crystallization process of the ZnO phase within the original pores of the g-C 3 N 4 phase.This results in the formation of an intimate contact interface between the ZnO phase and g-C 3 N 4 phase, which enhances the charge transfer and separation between the two phases.Fig. 4f presents the HRTEM image of the interface between the two phases.The ZnO phase exists as relatively small nanoparticles surrounded by the g-C 3 N 4 phase, conrming the existence of the interfacial contact proposed above.The denoted lattice fringes with a d spacing of 0.26 nm can be assigned to the (002) crystal plane of hexagonal wurtzite ZnO.46 In order to further conrm the above interfacial contact, the EDX mapping of the prepared G10 sample was performed to investigate the distribution patterns of the component elements.As seen from Fig. 5, all of the four major elements (C, N, Zn, and O) were uniformly distributed in the G10 sample.Combined with previous discussion, the homogenous distribution of the component elements also suggests that the g-C 3 N 4 phase and ZnO phase within G10 are indeed fully mixed and intimately contacted, rather than existing as separate aggregates in the G10 sample. specic surface area, pore volume and pore diameter are displayed in Table 1.As seen from Table 1, the pure g-C 3 N 4 (48.5 m 2 g A1 ) has a greater specic surface area than the obtained G10 sample (12.8 m 2 g A1 ), which is due to the addition of the ZnO phase.The rather low specic surface area of pure ZnO can be ascribed to the formation of rather large ZnO microcrystals with high crystallinity under the above synthetic conditions, which can be conrmed by direct SEM observation presented in Fig. 4a.isotherms of both G10 and g-C 3 N 4 belong to type IV, indicating the existence of mesopores (2-50 nm). 18Further observations reveal that the adsorption-desorption isotherm of g-C 3 N 4 generally shis upward relative to G10 in the whole relative pressure range, suggesting a 4 .Also, the results presented in Table 1 calculated by the BJH method show that pure g-C 3 N 4 has a larger pore volume and larger pore diameter than G10.The isotherms and pore size distributions in Fig. 6 are both consistent with the calculated results shown in Table 1.Moreover, the shapes of hysteresis loops of pure g-C 3 N 4 and G10 reect that both can be attributed to the type H3, indicating the presence of silt-like pores generated by particle aggregation.Based on the deduction that the crystallization of ZnO and the thermal condensation of g-C 3 N 4 occur simultaneously to form separate phases, the drastic decline of the specic surface area and pore volume of G10 implies that the crystallization of ZnO can ll up the original silt-like pores within the g-C 3 N 4 phase, which can
